more.translation[0].definitions[0].type: used before an adjective or adverb to form the comparative
more.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: having a particular quality to a greater degree
more.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: You’ll have to be more careful next time.
Can’t it be done more quickly?
Children generally feel much more confident working in groups.
It was a lot more expensive than I had expected.
Your health is more important than anything else.
Children can often do these puzzles more easily than adults.
Selling goods abroad is no more difficult  (=not more difficult) than selling to the home market.
more.translation[0].definitions[0].note_: More is not used before the -er form of an adjective or adverb You say
The train is quicker than the bus
more.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: used to say that something happens a greater number of times or for longer
more.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: I promised Mum that I’d help more with the housework.
You need to get out of the house more.
He travels around a lot more now that he has a car.
Children are using the library more than they used to.
more.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: used to say that something happens to a greater degree
more.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: She cares a lot more for her dogs than she does for me.
It’s his manner I dislike, more than anything else.
more.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: We should spend more on health and education.
Diane earns a lot more than I do.
Our plane took off more than two hours late.
More than a quarter of the students never finished their courses.
More people are buying new cars than ever before.
Viewers want better television, and more of it.
Perhaps next year more of us will be able to afford holidays abroad.
more.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: I really am interested. Tell me more.
Can I have a little more time to finish?
You’d better take some more of your medicine.
Don’t waste any more of my time.
more.translation[1].note_box[0].sections: more
in addition to an amount or number
Can I have some more coffee?
I have one more question.
It only costs a few dollars more.
further
as well as the ones that you have already mentioned
She will remain in hospital for further tests.
They waited for a further two hours.
supplementary
in addition to the main part of something
Supplementary information is available on request.
a supplementary question
supplementary income
extra
in addition to the usual or standard cost, time, amount etc
They let the kids stay up an extra hour.
Some stores charge extra for delivery.
Postage is extra.
additional
more than the basic amount or the amount that you expected or agreed. Additional  is more formal than extra
An evening job would provide additional income.
There may be an additional charge for paying bills by credit card.
